awd_titl_txt: Conference: Support for Mentors at the Division of Nuclear Physics Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for graduate students and postdocs while they learn mentoring skills and subsequently supports their participation in the Conference Experience for Undergraduates (CEU) that is part of the annual Division of Nuclear Physics (DNP) meeting.  As near-peer participants in the CEU, they will enhance the experience of the undergraduate students through individual and group meetings, physics discussions, and psychosocial support. In addition, the funding will enable participants to attend the conference and present their own research, discuss their work with members of the community, and further their own careers.  Institutionalizing a trained near-peer network at the DNP will continue to aid undergraduate students in developing a scientific identity that is essential for them to see themselves as future physicists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Division of Nuclear Physics (DNP) annual meeting brings together the country’s nuclear physicists to share the newest scientific discoveries. Among them are hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students, who are considering a career in nuclear science. These students will create the future workforce and contribute to a variety of fields from basic science to nuclear medicine and national security.  This grant worked to aid in the retention of both groups of students by supporting a near-peer mentoring network.

Twenty-three graduate students and postdoctoral researchers (near-peers) were recruited to mentor the undergraduate students in attendance.  The mentors participated in an 8-hour mentoring workshop and then practice these skills during the conference with their assigned undergraduate mentees. This included daily meet ups, practice presentations, and social events. 

Research has shown this type of model increases a participant’s scientific identity and sense of belonging, allowing them to make well informed decisions on their future career choices.

From the mentors surveyed, 95% would recommend this program to a friend and all found the mentorship program personally rewarding. In addition, two of the mentors would not have been able to attend and 10 noted it would have been much more difficult to attend the DNP conference and present their own scientific work without the support of this program.
